member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Wpf.SharpDX.DeferredRenderer.RenderGBufferOutput(HelixToolkit.Wpf.SharpDX.RenderContext,SharpDX.Direct3D11.Texture2D@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This render-function is use to directly display the 4 G-Buffer textures in one screen. It does not compute any lighting, it just copies the (resized) buffer-textures into the back-buffer. It is called per frame.

member.summary: Performs the currently activated blur pass on the content of ScreenSpaceBuffer 0. If renderTargetIndex is set to -1, the results are rendered to the default render targets, otherwise to the ScreenSpaceBuffer with the index renderTargetIndex (0-2). If the renderTargetIndex cannot be rendered to, the function chooses another ScreenSpaceBuffer and returns its index.

summary.para: Use HwndHost as rendering surface, swapchain for rendering. Much faster than using D3DImage.
Render on seperate rendering thread. EnableSwapChainRendering=True to use this rendering method.
Drawbacks: The rendering surface will cover all WPF controls in the same Viewport region. Move controls out of viewport region to solve this problem.
For displaying ViewCube and CoordinateSystem, separate Model needs to create to render along with the other models. WPF viewport will not be visibled.

Drawbacks: The rendering surface will cover all WPF controls in the same Viewport region. Move controls out of viewport region to solve this problem.
For displaying ViewCube and CoordinateSystem, separate Model needs to create to render along with the other models. WPF viewport will not be visibled.

member.name: T:HelixToolkit.Wpf.SharpDX.VisualTargetPresentationSource
member.summary: The VisualTargetPresentationSource represents the root of a visual subtree owned by a different thread that the visual tree in which is is displayed. https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/dwayneneed/2007/04/26/multithreaded-ui-hostvisual/
member.remarks:
A HostVisual belongs to the same UI thread that owns the visual tree in which it resides.
A HostVisual can reference a VisualTarget owned by another thread.
A VisualTarget has a root visual.
VisualTargetPresentationSource wraps the VisualTarget and enables basic functionality like Loaded, which depends on a PresentationSource being available.

summary.para: Enable deferred rendering. Not supported with EnableSharedModelMode = true
If this is enabled, seperate UI thread is created and used for rendering. Main UI thread is used to create command list for deferred context.
This does not guarantee better performance. Please fully test before deciding which rendering method being used.
Deferred Rendering:

summary.para: Enable deferred rendering. Not supported with EnableSharedModelMode = true
If this is enabled, seperate UI thread is created and used for rendering. Main UI thread is used to create command list for deferred context.
This does not guarantee better performance. Please fully test before deciding which rendering method being used.
Deferred Rendering:

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Wpf.SharpDX.Viewport3DX.EnableSharedModelMode
member.summary: Used to create multiple viewport with shared models.

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Wpf.SharpDX.Viewport3DX.SharedModelContainer
member.summary: Binding to the element inherit with

summary.para: Use HwndHost as rendering surface, swapchain for rendering. Much faster than using D3DImage.
Drawbacks: The rendering surface will cover all WPF controls in the same Viewport region. Move controls out of viewport region to solve this problem.
For displaying ViewCube and CoordinateSystem, separate Model needs to create to render along with the other models. WPF viewport will not be visibled.
Note: Enable deferred rendering will use seperate rendering thread or rendering.

summary.para: Viewbox replacement for Viewport using swapchain rendering.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Wpf.SharpDX.Utilities.TokenizerHelper.#ctor(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Constructor for TokenizerHelper which accepts an IFormatProvider. If the IFormatProvider is null, we use the thread's IFormatProvider info. We will use ',' as the list separator, unless it's the same as the decimal separator. If it *is*, then we can't determine if, say, "23,5" is one number or two. In this case, we will use ";" as the separator.
member.param: The string which will be tokenized.
The IFormatProvider which controls this tokenization.

member.name: T:HelixToolkit.Wpf.SharpDX.OffReader
member.summary: A Geomview Object File Format (OFF) reader.
member.remarks: The reader does not parse colors, normals and texture coordinates. Only 3 dimensional vertices are supported. Homogeneous coordinates are not supported. See the following links for information about the file format: http://www.geomview.org/ http://people.sc.fsu.edu/~jburkardt/data/off/off.html http://people.sc.fsu.edu/~jburkardt/html/off_format.html http://segeval.cs.princeton.edu/public/off_format.html http://paulbourke.net/dataformats/off/

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Wpf.SharpDX.ObjReader.SkipTransparencyValues
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to skip transparency values ("Tr") in the material files.
member.value: true if transparency values should be skipped; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: This option is added to allow disabling the "Tr" values in files where it has been defined incorrectly. The transparency values ("Tr") are interpreted as 0 = transparent, 1 = opaque. The dissolve values ("d") are interpreted as 0 = transparent, 1=opaque.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Wpf.SharpDX.ObjReader.AddFace(System.String)
member.summary: Adds a face.
member.remarks: Adds a polygonal face. The numbers are indexes into the arrays of vertex positions, texture coordinates, and normals respectively. A number may be omitted if, for example, texture coordinates are not being defined in the model. There is no maximum number of vertices that a single polygon may contain. The .obj file specification says that each face must be flat and convex.

member.name: T:HelixToolkit.Wpf.SharpDX.MeshBuilder
member.summary: Builds MeshGeometry3D objects.
member.remarks:
Performance tips for MeshGeometry3D (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb613553.aspx)
High impact: Mesh animationchanging the individual vertices of a mesh on a per-frame basisis not always efficient in Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF). To minimize the performance impact of change notifications when each vertex is modified, detach the mesh from the visual tree before performing per-vertex modification. Once the mesh has been modified, reattach it to the visual tree. Also, try to minimize the size of meshes that will be animated in this way.
Medium impact: When a mesh is defined as abutting triangles with shared vertices and those vertices have the same position, normal, and texture coordinates, define each shared vertex only once and then define your triangles by index with TriangleIndices.
Low impact: To minimize the construction time of large collections in Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF), such as a MeshGeometry3Ds Positions, Normals, TextureCoordinates, and TriangleIndices, pre-size the collections before value population. If possible, pass the collections constructors prepopulated data structures such as arrays or Lists.

member.name: T:Wpf3DTools.Trackball
member.summary:
Trackball is a utility class which observes the mouse events on a specified FrameworkElement and produces a Transform3D with the resultant rotation and scale.
Example Usage:
Trackball trackball = new Trackball(); trackball.EventSource = myElement; myViewport3D.Camera.Transform = trackball.Transform;
Because Viewport3Ds only raise events when the mouse is over the rendered 3D geometry (as opposed to not when the mouse is within the layout bounds) you usually want to use another element as your EventSource. For example, a transparent border placed on top of your Viewport3D works well:
NOTE: The Transform property may be shared by multiple Cameras if you want to have auxiliary views following the trackball.
It can also be useful to share the Transform property with models in the scene that you want to move with the camera. (For example, the Trackport3D's headlight is implemented this way.)
You may also use a Transform3DGroup to combine the Transform property with additional Transforms.

member.name: P:Wpf3DTools.Trackball.Transform
member.summary: A transform to move the camera or scene to the trackball's current orientation and scale.

member.summary: Rotation component of the transform

member.summary: The FrameworkElement we listen to for mouse events.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.MipMapCount
member.summary: A simple wrapper to specify number of mipmaps. Set to true to specify all mipmaps or sets an integer value >= 1 to specify the exact number of mipmaps.
member.remarks:
This structure use implicit conversion:
Set to true to specify all mipmaps.
Set to false to specify a single mipmap.
Set to an integer value >=1 to specify an exact count of mipmaps.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.PixelFormat

member.name: T:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.TextureDescription
member.summary: A Common description for all textures.
member.remarks: This class exposes the union of all fields exposed by fields in , , . It provides also 2-way implicit conversions for 1D, 2D, 3D textures descriptions.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.TextureDescription.Dimension
member.summary: The dimension of a texture.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.TextureDescription.Width

dd.p: Texture width (in texels). The range is from 1 to (16384). However, the range is actually constrained by the feature level at which you create the rendering device. For more information about restrictions, see Remarks.

member.remarks: This field is valid for all textures: , , and .
member.unmanaged: unsigned int Width

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.TextureDescription.Height

dd.p: Texture height (in texels). The range is from 1 to (2048). However, the range is actually constrained by the feature level at which you create the rendering device. For more information about restrictions, see Remarks.

member.remarks: This field is only valid for , and .
member.unmanaged: unsigned int Height

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.TextureDescription.Depth

dd.p: Texture depth (in texels). The range is from 1 to (2048). However, the range is actually constrained by the feature level at which you create the rendering device. For more information about restrictions, see Remarks.

member.remarks: This field is only valid for .
member.unmanaged: unsigned int Depth

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.TextureDescription.ArraySize

dd.p: Number of textures in the array. The range is from 1 to (2048). However, the range is actually constrained by the feature level at which you create the rendering device. For more information about restrictions, see Remarks.

member.remarks: This field is only valid for , and
This field is only valid for textures: , and .
member.unmanaged: unsigned int ArraySize

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.TextureDescription.MipLevels

dd.p: The maximum number of mipmap levels in the texture. See the remarks in . Use 1 for a multisampled texture; or 0 to generate a full set of subtextures.

member.unmanaged: unsigned int MipLevels

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.TextureDescription.Format

dd.p: Texture format (see ).

member.unmanaged: DXGI_FORMAT Format

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.TextureDescription.SampleDescription

dd.p: Structure that specifies multisampling parameters for the texture. See .

member.remarks: This field is only valid for .
member.unmanaged: DXGI_SAMPLE_DESC SampleDesc

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.TextureDescription.Usage

dd.p: Value that identifies how the texture is to be read from and written to. The most common value is ; see for all possible values.

member.unmanaged: D3D11_USAGE Usage

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.TextureDescription.BindFlags

dd.p: Flags (see ) for binding to pipeline stages. The flags can be combined by a logical OR. For a 1D texture, the allowable values are: , and .

member.unmanaged: D3D11_BIND_FLAG BindFlags

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.TextureDescription.CpuAccessFlags

dd.p: Flags (see ) to specify the types of CPU access allowed. Use 0 if CPU access is not required. These flags can be combined with a logical OR.

member.unmanaged: D3D11_CPU_ACCESS_FLAG CPUAccessFlags

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.TextureDescription.OptionFlags

dd.p: Flags (see ) that identify other, less common resource options. Use 0 if none of these flags apply. These flags can be combined with a logical OR.

member.unmanaged: D3D11_RESOURCE_MISC_FLAG MiscFlags

member.name: T:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.ViewType
member.summary: Defines how a view is selected from a resource.
member.remarks: This selection model is taken from Nuaj by Patapom (http://wiki.patapom.com/index.php/Nuaj)

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.ViewType.Full
member.summary: Gets a texture view for the whole texture for all mips/arrays dimensions.
member.example:
Here is what the view covers with whatever mipLevelIndex/arrayIndex
Array0 Array1 Array2 ______________________ Mip0 | X | X | X | |------+------+------| Mip1 | X | X | X | |------+------+------| Mip2 | X | X | X | ----------------------

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.ViewType.Single
member.summary: Gets a single texture view at the specified index in the mip hierarchy and in the array of textures The texture view contains a single texture element at the specified mip level and array index
member.example:
Here is what the view covers with mipLevelIndex=1 and mrrayIndex=1
Array0 Array1 Array2 ______________________ Mip0 | | | | |------+------+------| Mip1 | | X | | |------+------+------| Mip2 | | | | ----------------------

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.ViewType.ArrayBand
member.summary: Gets a band texture view at the specified index in the mip hierarchy and in the array of textures The texture view contains all the mip level texture elements from the specified mip level and array index
member.example:
Here is what the view covers with mipLevelIndex=1 and mrrayIndex=1
Array0 Array1 Array2 ______________________ Mip0 | | | | |------+------+------| Mip1 | | X | | |------+------+------| Mip2 | | X | | ----------------------

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.ViewType.MipBand
member.summary: Gets a band texture view at the specified index in the mip hierarchy and in the array of textures The texture view contains all the array texture elements from the specified mip level and array index
member.example:
Here is what the view covers with mipLevelIndex=1 and mrrayIndex=1
Array0 Array1 Array2 ______________________ Mip0 | | | | |------+------+------| Mip1 | | X | X | |------+------+------| Mip2 | | | | ----------------------
